description: From Middle English tune, an unexplained variant of tone, from Old French ton, from Latin tonus, from Ancient Greek τόνος (tónos, “a tone”). Doublet of tone, ton, and tonus.

entries.meaning: A song, or short musical composition.
(informal) The act of tuning or maintenance.
examples: Your engine needs a good tune.

entries.meaning: The state or condition of being correctly tuned.
examples: Your engine is now in tune.
This piano is not in tune.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A sound; a note; a tone.

verbs.description: tune (third-person singular simple present tunes, present participle tuning, simple past and past participle tuned)

entries.meaning: To adjust (a musical instrument) so that it produces the correct pitches.
examples: to tune a piano or a violin

entries.meaning: To adjust or modify (esp. a mechanical or electrical device) so that it functions optimally.
examples: Tuning the engine gave me an extra twenty horsepower.
Tune your mind, and anything becomes possible.

entries.meaning: To adjust the frequency on a radio or TV set, so as to receive the desired channel.
examples: Tune to Channel 6 for all your favourite daytime shows.

entries.meaning: Of faculties, senses, etc.: to adapt to or direct towards a particular target.
examples: My ears were tuned to the sounds of the forest.

entries.meaning: To make more precise, intense, or effective; to put into a proper state or disposition.
To attune; to adapt in style of music; to make harmonious.
(transitive) To give a certain tone or character to.
(obsolete) To sing with melody or harmony.
(transitive, South Africa, slang) To be impudent towards; to cheek.
(fandom slang) to adjust the parameters of singing voice synthesis software such as VOCALOID (in order to achieve certain singing techniques, increase the human quality of the voice, etc.)
